description.text: 3D model made for lovers. The heart was made from a bass and G clef

These mounts allow you to use an industrial silicone heating pad to heat the bed of your 3D printer.
The PC-board heating element in most 3D printer beds is a structural part of the assembly and supports the glass.  Since silicone heater pads are flexible, additional structure is needed.  These mounts go under each corner of the bed, supporting the heating pad and the glass.  Everything is held together with a binder clip.
Intall fiberglass insulation under the heating pad to keep it pressed up against the glass.  I used pipe wrap insulation from the hardware store, and I taped the strips together with Kapton tape.  You can add a thermistor between the flexible pad and the glass if the one built into the pad isn't suitable.
Silicone heating pads can be very powerful.  Make sure you have your thermistor configured correctly.  It's very easy to reach very high temperatures (>150C) very quickly if you have it misconfigured.

Printer:

MakerFarm Prusa i3v

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: I printed these in ABS. Just be sure the plastic you use will withstand the bed temperatures you plan to reach.

Installation You will need four mounts: one for each corner of your heated bed.
  • Tap the holes in the mounts with an M3 tap
  • Install one mount in each corner of the bed, using an M3 screw
  • Apply a layer of insulation
  • Lay the silicone heater pad on top of the mounts and insulation
  • Add a thermistor on top of the heater pad, if desired
  • Place the glass on top of the pad
  • Secure with binder clips.

comments.text: Can you still adjust the level of the printing bed by the screw while you put the mount in the four corners?
comments.author: Scotthu55

comments.text: I use auto bed leveling, so I haven't bothered leveling the bed.  You could shim with washers or maybe put springs under the mounts.  That could get pretty wobbly without the PC board heater for structure.
comments.author: Scotthu55

author: bustmold

title: Basic Cooling Fan Duct for Replicator 2

description.text: Super basic cooling fan duct I created for lack of having the correct duct.

comments.text:
Why the hell does everyone make ducts that blow onto the nozzle? Unless youre using a temperature script with laywood3 and no orbit, it will hurt your quality and temperature stability. The idea is to blow onto the model, and not with small, high speed ducts either or you screw up your bridges with down force. I feel like a lot of these people have no business designing things that require engineers and comprehension of physics and the machines to do properly. :( It needs to point down... and If you are printing laywood3, maybe make a removable door to open up to the nozzle heater block. But even if you redesigned it, that huge section that's facing the nozzle, will melt over time and while printing above 240. Remember the glass transition temp, not the melting temp, is what you need to worry about, which is much, much lower. You need insulation of some kind on this to stop that but I don't feel its even worth the time, its also designed for a ducted fan ,which is more expansive than a standard and has a smaller volume per minute than a regular fan, it also has lower pressure at the opening of the cooler, and thus slower exit speeds. Im sorry to sound like a dick here but every single duct on here for the replicator has these same flaws, this was just the one I gave up on. Ill just make my own in Max. Jesus people..... Do some research, seriously....
Now go on hating me for spewing truth and continue your lives.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text:
This duct works a treat on the Replicator 2.
If i may suggest an improvement, if the duct could point downward a bit more that would just be dandy. If you post your original files i might have a go at doing that. Thanks!

comments.text: Thanks for sharing. Works as good if not better than original.

description.text:
Designed for 5" props and smaller Print 2 Bases, 2 Posts, 2 Zeroers, and 1 Base Connector Requires:
2X 0.7" magnets 0.196" deep
1X at least 3" 8-32 Threaded rod
2X 8-32 nuts The magnets press-fit quite well into the PLA stands, but may require some sanding for a better fit and glue if needed.
To get a point on the ends of the threaded rod, I put one end into a drill and used a belt sander, spinning both the drill and sander to get a nice centered point on the rod. This is required until you have a reasonably sharp point and fits within the stands without creating a lot of friction.
All the parts to the stand are interlocking to mount to the other parts requiring a small amount of super glue.

author: n602

title: Solidoodle Jigsaw Replacement Extruder mk5 - Bowden

description.text: A modified version of my mk5 extruder, modified for bowden use. To suit an E3D mk5 bowden (and perhaps an E3D mk6 bowden). I saw that others had remixed my original design to convert it to bowden, but the E3D hardware didn't fit. This design should make the changeover straight forward because it provides a mount for the extruder at the top/rear of the printer and provides guides for 10mm conduit to tidy the wiring.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50%

Notes: Only part that needs support is the 'mk5_bowden_filament_guide_and_holder', to create the clamp to go on the frame. To simplify the design and speed up printing time, the equivalent piece from the original design can be substituted. The new design will provide a more stable mount for the extruder stepper.

Certain holes should be threaded (M3):
  • hole at base of the tension arm
  • locking arm pivot hole on body
  • x-axis end stop hole on body
    • All other small holes can be drilled out a perfect 3mm, except:
  • bore in extruder that PTFE tube goes through, which cn be drilled to 4mm
  • 11mm holes for conduit, which stay as is
  • 5mm holes in tension arm, which stay as is
  • 10mm hole on stepper body part, which can tapped at 1/8NPT27 to accept bowden fitting (you may have success simply force screwing the fitting in, but be careful not to damage the thread!)

comments.text: Dude you're a magician at Solidoodle upgrades. This one looks great, cant wait to tear down my extruder again...

print_settings.Resolution:: Depends on the activity you ave in mind.

description.text: This is a set of two similar triangles that can be used to teach the similar triangles unit in mathematics. Several activities can be done including taking the triangles, a piece of paper, ruler and a protractor to show that all sizes of the triangles have the same side length ratio as well as angles. as shown in the photo. Another piece is get the students to place the small triangle inside the larger one to show that they fit together, ( if they don't fit together the small one is upside down ;) ).

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Depends on the activity you ave in mind.

Infill:

Low, around 20% should do fine.

Notes: i had trouble printing it for a while, but once I used some green masking tape for some extra surface texture and a raft it worked just fine.
One of the exercise ideas.
I used 123D Design and Blender to make these.

Objectives: This is to help teachers teach students about similar triangles in an interactive way for all those kinesthetic learners out there. I always found that once i had something physical to compare a lesson to i always remembered it better. Audiences: Any grade of students learning about similar triangles could use this, they would probably, however, be in high school or grade 8. Preperation: All students need to know before hand is what a similar triangle is and then these activities can reinforce that knowledge. They should have different materials depending on the activity most of which will, however, require a ruler, protractor, pencil and paper. Steps: There are tons of activities you could use these in, however, i will describe one of them just to get your mind juices flowing.
  • Take a piece of paper and the triangles.
  • Get students to trace the triangles in several orientations and sizes.
  • Have them measure each angle.
  • Have them measure each side length.
  • Have them find the ratios between the side lengths.
  • Have them realize all the angles are the same.
  • Celebrate in a class well taught! :)
    • Results: This is more of an activity for learning and not assessment so I would suggest that they do not get graded on this, however, do as you will with the activities you create! By the end of this activity the students should have a set of triangles drawn on the page in different sizes that are all similar triangles and have gained the knowledge of how they work.

When you want to solder two cables together and dont have four arms to both solder and hold the cables.
All kind of cables fit into the different slots.
A "helping hand" can damage your cables, especially if the cables are hot. This design will protect your cables from that issue.
Put them in, and solder in the middle.

description.text:
I thought I'd add my own design to the slew of phone stands already out there. There isn't really anything special to this stand, it's just a rather large phone stand that holds your device at a 60 degree angle, and is held up by a stick person. 
In the picture, it's scaled to 146.9 mm, .2 mm layer height, 10% infill density, and it took 6.5 hours to print on a XYZ da Vinci 1.0. I have uploaded the .ipt file so you can customize it using Autodesk Inventor.

description.text:
I'm building a recumbent tadpole trike called the Warrior. I bought the plans from http://www.atomiczombie.com/main.aspx?click=plans , so I won't be uploading them, but these are some templates to help you neatly mark and cut the steel tubes. Templates:
  • a 90 degree notch. this is used to attach the rear-seat-tube to the rear-forks.
  • a 45 degree cut. This is used at the bottom of the rear-seat-tube and the tail end of the rear forks.
  • a 76.66 degree cut. This is used at the front/top of the centre-boom. I used the power of trig to get this angle.
    bonus all templates have a straight-cut built in. 2 templates in one object!
    • BETA these templates are currently untested. Also, I haven't worked out all the angles of the front forks yet, so there's no templates for those yet.

Don't print these: they don't work. Also, its about a 6 hour print on my ToM.
I'll post a rev2 soon.
  • print
  • slip template over steel tube
  • mark steel with a sharpie
  • remove template
  • cut steel
  • weld

author: rycoggs

title: Parabolic Mirror Mold for Collimated Display

description.text: This is a parabolic mirror mold I created for a collimated display. THIS IS A VERY LARGE PRINT  (2.37m x 1m x 0.5m  or ~93" x 39" x 20") and I am working on breaking it down into smaller interlocking pieces that can be printed on most printers. If you have the means to build it though, the focal point is 1.5m vertically from the bottom, and about 840mm from the back edge at the top (the name of the file suggests otherwise, but the principal point of reflection was cut from the mold making it slightly shorter front to back).

Inspired by a gentleman on the internet who constructed his own 220 degree collimated display using mylar and a vacuum, I decided to throw my hat into the ring.  It is roughly the same apsect ratio as an ultrawide monitor (21:9). It's no mind-blowing 220 degrees, but it is a true parabolic form (Y = X^2/4P) and should be able to create a decently sharp collimated image. Rather than the vacuum method, this is meant to have mylar stretched over the convex side, then painted with some sort of form-holding substance like bed liner or epoxy, where upon removing the mold one should have a concave mirror that holds its form permanently.

title: Customizable Cell Phone Charger Pad Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing holds a round wireless cell phone charging pad and the phone above it so that the phone is perfectly centered on the pad (and stays that way despite kids, pets, etc.)
About a month ago I ordered one of the round wireless charging pads that are common on the Internet.  It works great as long as the phone is placed perfectly centered on the pad.  If it is a little bit off (or the table gets bumped) it will not charge the phone.  I had gotten fairly good at placing the phone on the pad but I knew that I could use my 3D printer to make it easier.
This thing is customizable for any phone and round charging pad.

This is a base module that substitutes for one of the points in the excellent 12 point hanging star: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35866 and makes it a tree topper. Parametric OpenSCAD file attached so you can customize for your tree or bulb. Docking pentagonal ring fits star as is. Vent holes double as branch tip slots. Bulb slot for single E27 LED spot. Tweak as needed.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

sparse

Notes: Print right side up (large opening down). I printed the star points in natural translucent PETG. Beautiful design, easy print. This piece printed in green ABS. Raft recommended for ABS, probably not needed for PETG or PLA. Infill set at 20%, could be lower. No support needed. I made it heavy, worried about heat stress, but the LED "bulb" puts out so little, you could lighten it up. USE LED BULB ONLY! NOT RECOMMENDED FOR INCANDESCENT BULBS! Plug it in for a few hours and satisfy yourself that the heat isn't a problem before you put it on your flammable Christmas tree. I can hold the bulb I'm using in my hand comfortably when at maximum temp. Have fun.

Print 11 points and glue them up.  CA adhesive would work.  I really recommend Quick Grip instead.  Then print this piece to fill the gap.  Designed to hold a 3W RGB color changing LED E27 base bulb.  I got mine on Amazon for under $6 with IR remote.  Vent holes double as mount holes for tree tip branch (your tree may vary).  I also used a low profile light socket plug to connect to light string (see pics), also from Amazon.  Socket screws on below bulb mount, holding everything in place.  This was maximum height my printer could handle.

description.text:
Those dang Possums kept knocking out my roof vents and living inside our roof. They made lots of noise getting inside, waking us up at 4am - now they don't - I built them a Possum house and inside the roof is off limits.
My Vents also include 3D printed flywire - to keep any smaller flying buggy  pests away
They are held in place by (3D printed) clips at each end, and two 3D printed Joiners in the center.
Also, we have an older house, and I couldn't find any Imperial measurement replacements
The vent size is  201mm X 104mm
To install, push one 3D printed vent into the roof, screw in both joiners, then push in the other one and screw tight.

author: Bailey5531

title: 13" 3D Edge-lit Sign Base & Blank Template Version 2 (Make Your Own!)

description.text:
Watch as I make a sign using this project -> https://youtu.be/-Ywr-m5aidw Made on a CNC Benchtop PRO (https://youtu.be/hwblYO0vtHM) Simple Edge Lit Sign Base and blank 13x13x.5" to engrave your picture, logo or text onto. We used Fusion 360 to design the base and Vectric vCarve PRO for the engraved designs on the acrylic. To make: 3D Print or CNC the base (upper and lower). Note: If 3D Printing you can do it as one peice (though you need to solder the LED strip after passing the wire through. We used MDF for the initial version and ultimately ended-up using Aluminum for the rest. Materials Needed:
1) Material for base (3D Print: ABS/PLA CNC: MDF, Wood, Aluminum, etc. )
2) LED Strip & Controller (the kind you can cut and solder are easy to find and inexpensive)
3) 13"x13"x0.5" Cast Clear Acrylic (Local or Online plastic store such as TAP plastics will carry these). Tip: Mirror your text/graphics so you can engrave from the backside of the acrylic, this will look cleaner when viewed front the un-cut side! The transparent material is 13"x13"x1/2" cast clear acrylic from TAP Plastics. The sign was etched lightly with a 1/16" router end mill bit on our CNC Benchtop Pro machine. (gcode included here). http://www.cncrouterparts.com/benchtop-pro-cnc-machine-kit-p-314.html The stand is made of MDF in two pieces screwed and glued together. Would look nicer if you made it out of a hardwood, next time we make some we will probably use Bamboo. Lights are the typical LED RGB reels w/programable controller cut to fit (~13") and glued down to the base.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-Ywr-m5aidw" ></iframe>

This is a customizable name tag created in OpenSCAD and is part of a series of OpenSCAD lessons found below. The complete set of lessons can be found as part of this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1201466 The latest version of this thing can be found at GitHub: https://github.com/txoof/sliding_box

Identify a problem As part of a larger set of lessons I needed a small project that could be used to teach about the following topics:
  • OpenSCAD
  • Variables
  • Thingiverse Customizer
    • Define a Solution A simple, understandable project that could be used by students interested in learning more about OpenSCAD would be useful. Design Specifications The project must:
  • Include modules
  • Be customizable
  • Be easy to understand through step-by-step instructions
Introduction and Requirements
This is a set of lessons that will introduce a novice, but experienced OpenSCAD user to modular and parametric design.

• Students aged 7 and older with some coding experience
  • Users with some basic OpenSCAD experience
  • Users that wish to improve their OpenSCAD skills
  • Users that wish to learn the basics of Parametric Design/Customization
Math, Programming, Logical Thinking

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.8.F.A.2 - Functions can be represented in many ways...
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.8.F.B.4 - Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities

1.c - Use models and simulations to explore complex systems...
3.b - ...Ethically use information from a variety of sources.
4.b - Plan and manage activities to develop a solution or complete a project

The lessons were written to be used in a self-paced class with coaching from a teacher.  They could also be used by experienced students without coaching.
Each lesson should take about 20 minutes for a moderately experienced OpenSCAD user to complete.

Students will learn...
  • How to use variables
  • How to use modules
  • How pass variables
  • How to write a module
  • The basics of parametric design
  • How to create customizable SCAD files
  • How to add a customizable Thing to Thingiverse
  • A little about licenses
  • How to manipulate other's OpenSCAD code

Students will...
  • Have a greater understanding of OpenSCAD variables and modules
  • Create a functioning, customizable sliding top box model with x and y dividers
  • Create a customizable name plate
  • Have a basic understanding of Open Licenses and Copyright
  • Have a basic understanding of parametric design practices

At the end of the lesson a successful student will have created a variation of the customizable name plate. A satisfactory design should include the following:
  • An OpenSCAD file that successfully compiles
  • The output should include a name-plate that includes the student's name or any other specified text
  • A working customizer instance of their project on Thingiverse
  • The ability to customize the following:
    • plate length
    • plate height
    • plate thickness
    • text size
    • text thickness
  • The uploaded model should cite this lesson as a source
  • The uploaded model should generate a valid STL file that is printable
All required assets are attached to this document

• OpenSCAD 2015.03 or greater
  • Basic Understanding of OpenSCAD
    • Basic understanding of the OpenSCAD language format
    • Ability to draw primitives
    • Ability to transform objects (rotate, translate, etc.)
    • Ability to union() and difference() objects
• A Thingiverse account for customizing models
• See lessons below
If you are unfamiliar with OpenSCAD, or need a bit of a refresher please start with Lesson 1 found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1201466

Begin your own Customizable Project You have enough experience now to begin creating your own customizable project. Along the way we will learn about the Thingiverse customizer and adding your own customized projects. Part of each section will include some sample code and a problem to solve. You will be creating a customizable name plate like the one shown here. Img 6.0 Comment Blocks:
When OpenSCAD sees this // it ignores everything from the last slash to the end of the line. This is handy for leaving notes to yourself or others. Sometimes comments need to extend over multiple lines. When OpenSCAD sees /* */ everything between the stars is ignored. This is called a 'comment block.' Thingiverse Customizer:
The customizer uses special comment blocks to help the customizer do its magic.
  • Open a new OpenSCAD project and create header like the one below. This is a Tab header for the customizer.

/* [Base] */ 2. Look at the example image and think about the variables and values you will need to create the base. What variables should your users be able to adjust? Add some well named variables below that will set the X, Y and Z size of the base.
3. Create a module for drawing a base and call the module. Make sure this compiles.
module base() { } base(); 4. Add instructions to the base module to draw a rectangular base using the variables you created earlier. If you used different variables, feel free to use them.

module base() { cube([xSize, ySize, zSize], center = true) } base(); 5. Challenge: Use a roundedBox() instead of a cube() for the base. You will need to import MCAD/boxes.scad. Learn more at the OpenSCAD wiki.

• What other variables do you think you will need in creating this project?
  • Make a list of the variables you think you will need.
  • Make a list of the modules you think you will need as you complete this project.

Add customizable mounting holes You should have code that looks something like this now: /* [Base] */ xSize = 45; // lenght of name tag ySize = 15; // height of name tag zSize = 3; // thickness of name tag module base() { cube([xSize, ySize, zSize], center = true) } module base() Img 7.0
  • Add a variable under the [Base] configuration for the hole diameter.
  • Create a new module that makes two holes in the corners of the base. Start with the code provide below and try to move the holes so they are both 1/2 of the diameter from the edge. Copy and paste this just above the base() module.

module holes() { translate([-xSize/2, ysize/2, 0]) // create a cylinder with 36 segments that is 2 times the thicknes of the base translate([-xSize/2+holeDia, ySize/2, 0]) #cylinder(r = holeRad, h = 2*zSize, $fn = 36, center = true); translate([xSize/2-holeDia, ySize/2, 0]) #cylinder(r = holeRad, h = 2*zSize, $fn = 36, center = true); } 3. Add a call just below the base() call to make the holes appear. Your code should look like this: Img 7.1

• What did you do to make sure the holes were 1/2 of the diameter from the edge?
  • Why is this method better than hard-coding in a number for the placement of the holes?
  • How does using a formula or equation help make this thing more customizable?

Adding extruded text In openscad 2015.03 text support was added officially. Using the linear_extrude() built-in raised and embossed text can be easily added to projects. The linear_extrude() module has many features. We will only be using it in the most simple form here. See the OpenSCAD wiki for more information on other features. Your next task is to add a module that will provide extruded text. Sometimes it is helpful to turn everything else off while you are working on a new feature. This can be done by simply adding a // in front of any line that you do not wish to execute. Think back to the list of variables you made in the previous lessons. What variables do you think will be needed for the text? Img 8.0

  • Comment out the base() and holes() modules:

    //base();
    //holes();

    • 2. Create a variable block for customizing text under the [Base] block:

*/ [Text] */ textHeight = 2; // height over base textSize = 7.5; // text size myColor = "yellow" // color in rendering myFont = "Liberation Sans" // more on this later! 3. Create a module for creating extruded text:

module textExtrude() { // the following four lines are all actually one command that ends with the ';' color(myColor) linear_extrude(height = textHeight) text("My Name", halign = "center", valign = "center", size = textSize, font = myFont); } 4. Test out your code; make sure everything else is commented out

//base(); //holes(); textExtrude(); 5. This project is super boring with "My Name" on the plaque. Let's make that customizable. Add another variable under the [Text] block for customizing the text. Make sure you use that variable appropriately in the extrude module.

• What did you need to do to make the text more customizable?
  • What do you think we need to do to join all these pieces together?
Joining it all together

• Practice calling one module from another
  • Practice using union()
    • Right now we have three separate parts that look like they are joined together. In some cases, this can be exported as an STL and it will indeed print properly on a 3d Printer. The text is not correctly placed however. Also, if we've made any errors in our placement of objects we may end up with something that looks printable, but that is actually impossible to print. We can solve this by joining everything together using OpenSCAD's union() and difference() modules. These are in the class of boolean opperations and could be a whole set of lessons in themselves.
  • Create a module that contains all the separate modules we need to make the name plate. Call the module makeTag()
  • Check that everything looks like the sample image. Notice that the holes are filled in and that the text is too low on the name plate. We will fix that now!
    • Img 9.0 - step 2 3. In the module we need to union() the text and the base. The text needs to be raised up so it appears the proper height over the base. Start with the code below and try to figure out how to raise the text so it is EXACTLY the height of base from the origin. Also try to move the text so it doesn't run into the holes.
module makeTag() { union() { base(); translate([0, 0, 0]) textExtrude(); } #holes() // turn on debug highlighthing to make this easier to see }
Removing unwanted bits

• Practice using difference()
  • Practice thinking parameterically
    • You were probably tempted to move the text using hard-coded values like this: module makeTag() { union() { base(); translate([0, -3, 1.5]) textExtrude(); } } Img 10.0 That should put the text just about out of the way of the holes, but the text size is adjusted or the base size is changed, the text will look a bit odd. Img 10.1 Instead consider moving the text so that it moves relative to the size of the base. Just like the holes, the text will move with the size of the base rather than being static. In this example the text moves down by 1/5 of the ySize and the text floats exactly at the surface of the base. module makeTag() { union() { base(); translate([0, -ySize/5 , zSize/2]) textExtrude(); } } Finally you need to add the mounting holes using difference(). Difference starts with the top level object (first listed) and then begins removing each subsiquent object from the first any where the objects intersect. In this case the union() of base and text makes an new single object.
1. Add a difference() statement to module makeTag()

module makeTag() { difference() { union() { base(); translate([0, -3, 1.5]) textExtrude(); } //end union } // end difference } // end makeTag() 2. Check that the result looks like the image above. Nothing should have been subtracted yet.
3. Add a call to the holes() module below the union()statement to make the mounting holes

module makeTag() { difference() { union() { base(); translate([0, -3, 1.5]) textExtrude(); } //end union } // end difference #holes(); // turn on debuging to check the location, remove the '#' once done } // end makeTag()
  • The final model should look like this:

• Make the base a different color
  • Use multiple fonts
  • Use multiple shapes for the base
  • Make a hexagonal base or a star shaped base

• What are some of the benefits for making models parametric?
  • What are some of the disadvantages of hard-coding values?
  • Explain how you think the difference and union commands work to someone else.
Preparing to publishing to Thingiverse

• Setup variables for Customizer
    • The last step is to publish this thing onto the Thingiverse. Once you have published it anyone with an account can use the Customizer to make derivative things. This is great! You can share you ideas with other people and they can run with your ideas and make them bigger, more atristic, more rediculous and generally more awesome. The first step is making sure your thing is easy to customize. We've started out on the right foot by creating logical variable tabs and giving the variables sensible names: /* [Base] */ xSize = 45; // length ySize = 15; // height zSize = 3; //thickness holeDia = 3.5; // hole diameter /* [Text] */ textHeight = 2; textSize = 7.5; myFont = "Liberation Sans"; myColor = "yellow"; The next step is to take advantage of some of the Customizer Markup. Any variable without specific markup will simply be a user-input field. Img 11.0 Sometimes we want to limit the range of valid inputs. This can be done by using a range. 1. Add a range using the following format: // [minimu:maximum] description

/* [Text] */ textHeight = 2; // [1:10] height of text over base textSize = 7.5; // [1:50] It is also possible to add a drop down menu of pre-populated options using list. Here's an opportunity to return to the font face choice. In version 2015.03-2 it is possible to use all of the system-installed fonts, but those fonts are not available on Thingiverse. Check the documenation wiki for more information on [fonts](https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/The_OpenSCAD_Language#Text] and colors. 2. Add a list of options using the following format: // [option1, option2, option3] myFont = "Liberation Sans"; // [Liberation Mono, Liberation Sans, Liberation Sans Narrow and Liberation Serif] myColor = "yellow"; // [green, yellow, blue, red, silver, black] Text color One other useful customizer section is the /[Hiden]/ section. This section, as the name implies is hidden from view. This is a great spot to do calculations or set up variables for use elsewhere. If you know that you will be dividing a variable by 2 every time you use it Such as the holeDiameter, set this value in the Hidden section. When writing a program, if you do something more than twice by hand, you should consider finding another way of doing it. Every time you divide by 2, or add two variables together manually you risk a typo that you will need to find and correct later. By limiting the number of times you make a particular calculation debugging and changes become much, much easier. 3. Add a /* [Hidden] */ section and add a variable for holeRad = holeDia/2;
4. Update your code to use holeRad in the holes() module.

• What types of variables in this project should be set as a range?
  • What things should be set as a drop down list? Why?
  • Can you think of a specific instance where you would want to prevent a user from inputting a specific value? What about when division is involved?
  • How can the [Hidden] section be useful to you as a designer? How is it useful to other people that review your designs?
  • How can setting variables under the Hidden section save you from errors later?
Getting ready to publish

• Create an account on thingiverse
  • Become familiar with Copyright licenses
  • Choose an appropriate copyright license for this project
    • The final step in this is to upload your project to Thingiverse so other people can play with it, improve on it and share their work. There are a few things you will need to do before you can share this project.
  • Create an account
  • Choose a License
    • Creating an account should be pretty self-explanitory. If you want to skip this step, continue on for some last little tid-bits. Here's a really interesting fact about Copy Right. You already have it. Once you hit the save key, you created a piece of work that can be copyrighted. The act of creation is all it takes. You have the sole right to decide who will use your work and how it will be used. Most of the stuff you see on the Thingiverse is copyrighted, but copyrighted in such a way that preserves the creators reputation, but allows anybody to make stuff and have fun with it. This is done through choosing a license that matches how you feel about your work. Is your work super secret and the basis of your billion dollar business plan? Don't share it! Keep that to your self! Or is your work a good idea based on the good ideas of all those that have come before you? Or something in between? How would you feel about someone using your idea to make something new? How would you feel about someone profiting from your work? Once you've answered those questions the next steps should be easy. Take a look at the Creative Commons license page and see which license works best for you. There's a nice little 3 minute video that explains the basics of the licenses. Choosing a license is not complex, but does require a bit of thought. This set of lessons that you have been reading is released under the Creative Commons Attribute-Share-Alike License. This means that if you want to publish your own version of the sliding top box or the name tag you should give me credit and you need to share your designs under the same terms, allowing others to modify and share the work as well. It also means that you can't sell the design. You are welcome to make real objects based on the design and sell them, but you can not take credit for the designs and sell those as your own. Giving credit is as simple as providing a user name, or an email address somewhere in your project. When you share your project on Thingiverse, or any other web site, you should also mention that your project is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribute-Share-Alike license so other people know where it came from. Thingiverse also provides GPL licenses and BSD license. These are more specific and apply more to software than creative works, but can be applied to almost anything. Because this project was originally released under the CC Share-Alike license, you really should choose the same license. I won't hunt you down and point a loaded lawyer at you, but I might give you a hard time if I come across one of your designs that is licensed in a more restrictive way. Finally you should also mark your project as a remix of this project (1204005). It give due credit to the author (me) and give you a warm fuzzy feeling knowing that you've properly credited the original author. Again, I won't point a lawyer at you, but I definitely will give you a hard time if I find your name tag project out there on the we with no reference to this project.

• Why would you bother to copyright your work at all?
  • Why should you respect the copyright of other's work?
  • Why should you cite this project when creating your project?
  • Which license did you choose for this project? Why? Hint: there are only a few right answers to this questions.
  • Which license is best for work that you intend to share with the community?
Uploading your project for customization

• Publish a customizable project to Thingiverse
    • The final step is to get your project up on the Thingiverse and get the customizer running. You will probably need to do some debugging and upload the files a few times; that's pretty normal.
  • Create an STL and a PNG of your design in OpenSCAD; this will give you a nice image to share
    • F6 to Render
    • File > Export > Export as STL
    • File > Export > Export as Image
  • Sign in to your Thingiverse account and choose 'Create > Upload a Thing'
  • Drag or Browse to upload your STL, PNG and SCAD file for your project
    • Drag the thumbnails to organize the images in the order that suits you
  • Give your project a catchy name that is descriptive but short
  • Select a category. This fits well under Art > Signs and Logos
  • Choose a license. This project was originally distributed under the CC Atrrib-Share-Alike license. It would be best to share this project under the same license as that is keeping in the spirit of the Creative Commons and the original author's (my) wishes.
  • Tick the 'This is a Remix' box because you derived this from someone else's project
    • In the box below you can specify the project this was derived from (1201466)
    • This helps others see the lineage of the project and locate other users that are working on similar projects.
    • This is also nice for me because I get a little notice every time someone uses my work. It's like a little tip in my jar, but I can't spend it. It just makes me feel good.
  • Tick 'This is a Customizer' to make sure this project is customizable.
  • Add one or two sentences summary that explains what this project is all about
  • If you would like to add any other instructions or notes you can use the Design section and the custom sections. This is not necessary, but can be nice.
  • Save and view your project.
    -Now's the time to test the customizer.
    -Make sure the customizer options appear as you expect. Make sure that things work like you hope.
    -If you need to make changes, edit the project and remove the SCAD file. Replace it with a revised version and then repeat step 11 as needed.
  • Publish your thing using the link at the top of the page and share it with all your friends.
    • Congratulations! You've just created your first customizable, parametric project and shared
    it on Teh Intertubes!

Thanks for making it this far. I hope you found this text useful and feel more confident using OpenSCAD and making parametric designs.
The next step is to download other people's libraries and SCAD projects and play with them. You can learn more from experimenting with other projects than I can teach you here. If you get stuck, don't hesitate to contact the person who created a project. Most authors will be thrilled to hear from someone who found their project useful. The urge to share ideas and learn from others is why most authors publish their works in places like the Thingiverse.
If you have any questions or comments for me please don't hesitate to contact me either through the Thingiverse or via email. I am happy to answer questions and would love to fix any mistakes you find.

description.text:
Thanks to the work from SerxioSierra and barspin, I remixed their works and made it work for my Fitbit Charge HR. I changed is the location of the USB charger hole. I also made the hole smaller so it'd really hold the USB cable securely so you can press the Fitbit Charge HR directly into it without worrying about the cable popping out. Also, I added a little cable retainer at the back. Unfortunately this bit will require supports when you print it. Since the rest of the model prints nicely on its side without supports, I have two STL files you can choose from:
  • fitbit_charge_hr_stand.stl has the cable retainer, the retainer part needs supports!
  • fitbit_charge_hr_stand_no_retainer does not have the retainer, and does not need supports
    • I did stick a few silicon sticky feet to make sure it doesn't go anywhere on the desk.

Printer:

Craftbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm Layer Height / 0.3 mm Extrusion Width

Infill:

20%

Notes: I sliced the model with Craftware 1.13. Manually drew in a few supports under the cable retainer. And printed it with OctoPrint. Total print time was about 4.5 hrs at 40mm/s drawing speed and uses about 4.8m of filament.

title: Mk8 Extruder for Nema17 with BI v2.5 mount

description.text:
This is a compact extruder using Mk8 gear and largely original parts from BI. I wanted a better extruder than EZstruder, using cheaper Mk8 gear for EU market, and with many features:
  • Continuous loading. Runout of plastic mid-print? Just load another.
  • Teflon tube is inserted closer to the gear to reduce friction.
  • Recommended using E3D Bowden mount for less tube destruction.
  • Higher torque than EZ as the Mk8 gear is smaller and has better teeth.
  • No more axial slipping by using V profile bearing.
  • Controllable spring force.
  • Fast loading.
    ...
    • BOM and instruction is in the PDF file.
    The fan mount is the same as my previous design. I will update more Bowden mounting versions soon and improve instruction so lookout for updates.

Printer:

BI v2.5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

Preferably 100%

Notes: This was design to be printed with 0.5mm nozzle with minimum 3 shells.
Infill should be as much as you can for strength.
Layer height is 0.1 for bearing mount and 0.25 for the rest.
Print the refined version if you can to archive rectangle holes for better mounting.

title: (no more) The best Anti-Wobbling Z-axis for Geeetech

description.text:
Hi all,
I have the ultimate solution to the problems of wobbling of the Z axis for the printer Geeetech Prusa I3 X with acrylic frame.
Simply using a hole saw, freed the two threaded rods and magically disappear the problems of wobbling.
Do not add more pieces to the printer to reduce the problem, freeing the two threaded rods will avoid threaded rods to go wrong and move the carriage during printing
Looks at my solution!!!! :)
If you want, you can also print the new part.... This is a good solution but no more the best one... ;)

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

comments.text:
Restricting both end of the threaded rod is not a good thing.
Its been engineered to be loose, that way when the threaded rod wobbles, will not put pressure on the smooth rod..
To restrict Both ends of the threaded rods, you must have all four roads perfectly parallel and exactly at the same plane, otherwise, a little .005 Inche misalignment from top to bottom, means ,0025 inch that the threaded rod will push the smooth rod to the sides. Think about an archers bow, if you hold both ends and rotate it, the middle of the arc will be wobbling, now, if you hold one end and the center of the arch, the other end will wobble and that is what is happening with the loose end..
E.g. If the threaded rod is not restricted and want to wobble to the left, nothing happens to the smooth rods,
If the threaded rod is restricted and want to wobble to the left, the middle of the threaded rod will push the smooth rods to the right..
Also the acme thread has been used not because is cheap but because is loose and the threaded rod will move freely from side to side within the idler without exerting pressure on the smooth rods.
comments.author: ranita

comments.text:
I do not think, it is a joke.
Replacing the original top plate by this thing might weaken the strength of it though.
I would only recommend this part, if the lead screw is really bent and is hitting or grinding the (often very wide designed) original hole there.
In your case, it really seemed to have been very small at first (your 2nd foto).
For my acrylic A6 it was enough, to cover the hole and even reduce the size by doing so - just for optical reasons...
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1867669
comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text: I may be late but just saw this so my warning !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: If you don't like this... don't use it, it's simple!!
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Of course I won't, I devised a real solution for this"wobbl" but it is my duty to warn beginners not to waste their time !
comments.author: jerryciano

comments.text: Even a beginner knows that two points are always on the same straight line, as three points are always on the same flat plane. So, as building a three-legged table avoids instability problems with uneven floors, so keeping just two mechanical constraints on the screw (the motor and the nut) is a perfectly viable and easy solution to relieve stresses and avoid wobble caused by slightly bent screws. Because this is the problem: we're talking about hobby product and chinese quality here. If you're lucky, you'll never see the kind of wobble this workaround fixes.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Just because three point are in the same plane, does not mean they are in the same axis and if the threaded rod wobbles is because the middle of the threaded rod is not in the same axis as the end points. Example: If you get an archers bow and grab it in the middle of the arc and one end, then rotate it and the other end will wobble; now grab the two ends, rotate it and the middle will wobble, If you do the same to the threaded rod, is thru that the ends will not wobble but the middle will and this wobble will exert force to the smooth rods. I made the mistake of installing them in my printer thinking only on the wobbling move, but did not think about the effect on the smooth rods until my parts did not meet tolerances vertically. solution was to remove the anti-wobbling.
comments.author: Axeman72

comments.text:
OK so you know basic geometry but obviously not much in mechanic !
It works for you ? So ? You don't eliminate the wobble, you just "reduce" it somewhat.
See, the first thing to do is to identify the cause, then eliminate it and if you can't eliminate it, try to minimize it.

"See, the first thing to do is to identify the cause, then eliminate it and unless you can't eliminate it, try to minimize it."

Perhaps you do not even have an acrylic geeetech prusa printer, so what are you talking about? I hope that in your fairy world of fairies and fates everything is always wonderful !!!

I bet the people who bought the acrylic version did it because of the "professional" label.
And my Geetech Al, I improved it by eliminating the wobble cause plus plenty of other problems. I published some of them, just the one requiring basic skills and knowledge.

comments.text: I'm an engineer, but also a realist. Please don't try and elevate your status because you have a degree. I spend half my day up to the knees in mud working with tradesmen making life easier for everyone. I'm not an overpaid desktop engineer. but a real one. I bought the acrylic machine, why because the best engineering is done in the field, by trial and error.

If you want to learn from your errors, you are welcome. Personally I prefer first to learn from other people's errors !
Saves at lot of time and the errors I can make then are at least major screw ups I can learn a lot more from ! :)

comments.author: drixtc

comments.text: Seems like they were going for a more stable design with the constraints. But after installing this my rods went from dancing to straight smooth movements. Definitely improved the print quality! Thanks for sharing this!!!
comments.author: Fokaisnake

comments.text: Glad to see that someone agrees with me on this! I have tried telling people that over constraining the threaded rod only makes it worse.
comments.author: Lugnut_91

comments.text: I'm happy to share my improvement for the printer, thanks for your comment. I think that the best solution is to free the top of the rod. Another good method is to reduce the diameter of the rod, for example from 8mm to 4mm, the 4mm threaded rods does not have the force to move the X-axis.
comments.author: jerryciano

comments.text: Good point, I hadn't thought about that.  Although I upgraded to the 8mm ACME leadscrews.
comments.author: jerryciano

comments.text: I am glad to see someone using a proper method of reducing threaded rods from applying forces to the X axis.  Restricting the top of the rod only makes things worse unless your threaded rods are PERFECTLY straight and perfectly centered in the stepper motor couplings.  Shimming the bottom of the rods so that they are centered in the couplers and checking to rods to make sure that they are straight eliminates the need to do anything more.  Rolling the rods on a flat surface (granite countertops work great) and tweaking them straight helps tremendously.
comments.author: kmags

author: snagman667

title: Geeetech Prusa I3 X Z-Leadscrew Top Support

description.text:
Geeetech Prusa I3 X Z-Leadscrew Top Support For 8mm rods @ 27mm centers (from Smoothrod to Leadscrew). Bearing:
Outer diameter (mm): 12
Inner diameter (mm): 8
Width (mm): 3.5
Type: MR 128ZZ Fix to Top Plate with M3 x 20mm Cap Head screw and nut. Note: This is not a fix for Z axis wobble. If you have any bend or misalignment in your Z axis this will potentially make it worse. This for straight Leadscrew or Threaded rod only. I did this mod because the Leadscrew tried to grab the Acrylic and I could see in a short time of printing the thread eating away at the acrylic. Fixing this could be optional but here is what I did: With the Leadscrew or threaded rod hole still "on size" (8mm) push the bearing into the support.
Slide the support over the smoothrod and leadscrew Note there is a left and a right.
Drill the 3mm hole.
Remove the Support and open the Leadscrew hole to something like 9mm. Note only the Leadscrew hole!
Bolt the support back in place and let the bearing do all the hard work.

Adapter for your K9 flash accessories.
If you have more than one flash and want to share the accessories between them, one is not enough.
3D printer to the rescue. Print as many adapters as you have flashes. Here is the link to the flash accessory kit:
http://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00CPK7BRI
http://www.gadgetinfinity.com/falcon-eyes-premium-lighting-kit-sga-k9-for-portable-flash.html

Print one K9 adapter and four strap holders.
Attach the strap holders to the adapter using #4 X 3/8" countersink wood screws.
Thread 1" wide Velcro strap through the strap holders. You need about 12".
You also need four 1"x1", 1/8" thick self-adhesive rubber or foam pads for better grip, and not mar your flash. Adhere them to the inside of each strap holder. The adapter is design for the Canon 580EX and the Yongnuo YN568EX. It will probably fit other flashes by adjusting the thickness of the rubber pads.
